title: Prosecutor Omalley Calls Potential Agreement With Cleveland To Jail Low Level Offenders 12 Hours Without Charges Morally Wrong.html
content: **Prosecutor O’Malley calls potential agreement with Cleveland to jail low-level offenders 12 hours without charges ‘morally wrong’** Updated:Jun. 11, 2025, 3:46 p.m. |Published:Jun. 11, 2025, 3:40 p.m. Cuyahoga County Prosecutor Michael O'Malley spoke out against a policy in a new potential contract to house Cleveland inmates in the county jail that would allow individuals accused of low-level offenses to be held up to 12 hours without charges. O'Malley called the proposal "morally wrong."Cory Shaffer, cleveland.com Kaitlin Durbin, cleveland.com CLEVELAND, Ohio – Cleveland and Cuyahoga County are close to striking a new contract to end the ongoing dispute over jailing city inmates, but Prosecutor Michael O’Malley, whose office played a role in the negotiations, is already seeking changes, calling it “unacceptable” and “morally wrong.” O’Malley was specifically referring to a policy in the new contract, which has yet to be formally introduced, that allows individuals accused of low-level felonies and misdemeanors to be detained in the county jail for up to 12 hours without charges.
